Number one, the 1994 law had nothing to do with assault weapons. Assault weapons are defined by several features including selective fire (the ability to switch betweem semi-automatic and automatic fire). Automatic weapons have been highly regulated since 1934 and are owned by an extremely small number of the general public. The weapons covered by the 1994 law were semi-automatic weapons which superficially resembled automatic weapons and were in absolutely no way functionally different than an array of weapons not covered by the ban. They looked scary is all.
 
 Number two, nothing was banned from ownership. The 1994 law affected the importation and manufacture of said weapons but did not prohibit ownership or sale of a single weapon. In fact, gun shows abounded with these weapons during the law's lifetime. How exactly can the streets now be flooded with them if they were always legal to own?
 
 On another note, the idea that we are now an armory for Mexican gangs is a joke. The notion that 90% of firearms used by the gangs come from the U.S. has been completely debunked, yet is still regularly regurgitated (try closer to 8%). Can someone please tell me exactly which gun shops here in the States sell grenades, rocket launchers, and machineguns? I'm pretty sure that if they are playing around with those, they aren't coming from here.

Subject: Fw: Vermont's Sensible Gun Registration Plan 
 
 1. Good morning Folks. What do you think of this idea? It does have an ironic appeal. 
 
 Vermont State Rep. Fred Maslack has read the Second Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, as well as Vermont's own Constitution very carefully, and his strict interpretation of these documents is popping some eyeballs in New England and elsewhere. 
 
 Maslack recently proposed a bill to register "non-gun-owners" and require them to pay a $500 fee to the state. Thus Vermont would become the first state to require a permit for the luxury of going about unarmed and assess a fee of $500 for the privilege of not owning a gun. 
 
 Maslack read the "militia" phrase of the Second Amendment as not only affirming the right of the individual citizen to bear arms, but as a clear mandate to do so. He believes that universal gun ownership was advocated by the Framers of the Constitution as an antidote to a "monopoly of force" by the government as well as criminals. 
 
 Vermont's constitution states explicitly that "the people have a right to bear arms for the defense of themselves and the State" and those persons who are "conscientiously scrupulous of bearing arms" shall be required to "pay such equivalent." Clearly, says Maslack, Vermonters have a constitutional obligation to arm themselves, so that they are capable of responding to "any situation that may arise." 
 
 Under the bill, adults who choose not to own a firearm would be required to register their name, address, Social Security Number, and driver's license number with the state. "There is a legitimate government interest in knowing who is not prepared to defend the state should they be asked to do so," Maslack says. 
 
 Vermont already boasts a high rate of gun ownership along with the least restrictive laws of any state. It's currently the only state that allows a citizen to carry a concealed firearm without a permit. This combination of plenty of guns and few laws regulating them has resulted in a crime rate that is the third lowest in the nation.
